metadata.synopsis: A dangerous airborne virus threatens civilization in this tense thriller. After an African monkey carrying a lethal virus is smuggled into the U.S., an outbreak occurs in a California town. To control the spread of the disease, a team of doctors is brought in that includes a contagious disease expert (Dustin Hoffman) and his ex-wife (Rene Russo). Once the Army intervenes to handle the situation, though, the doctors must fight against the clock to save the town and its residents.

reviews: The whole movie is so intensely melodramatic and unbelievable...
Don't expect any mercy from the people who made "Outbreak," a smashingly first-rate thriller that will do more to rev your pulse rate than a week of aerobics classes.
The first hour was intriguing, but it is gross and nasty...
Regardless of how ridiculous this movie was, it's extremely entertaining.
'90s medical disaster movie has violence, peril, language.
It may all be a tad hammy... but the fear is palpable. Fear the sneeze.
It mixes spectacular action, high-flying intrigue and even terror in an apparent but banal pastiche that, to top it all, tries to transcend its premises. [Full Review in Spanish]
You could read this as an Aids allegory, but it also works well as a regular against-the-clock jeopardy thriller with conspiracy cover-up overtones.
Outbreak isn't a perfect movie, but it is the perfect movie to talk about the way pop culture portrays viruses...
Petersen pulls off the thrills at a stomach lurching pace, and with its requisite Hollywood ham...
It's a weird kind of comfort food: as bad as it seems for us, at least it's not as bad as what's in the movies.
Petersen's vigilant, enlivening direction never allows the story's death-of-mankind topic to undermine its personal powers, deftly mixing in humor, as well as other tonal lighteners, to nurture it.
The film is less effective, unfortunately, at trusting its audience to remain invested in Cedar Creek's drama, which results in two grating subplots that become the A-plot in the draggy third act.
Outbreak isn't a terrible film, but it doesn't trust that relative realism has enough power to hook and hold a movie audience.
Outbreak will keep you on the edge of your scat, and every time someone sneezes or coughs in the audience, you'll pay attention.
A solid '90s thriller...
Much too enamored by its Hollywood trappings to deliver a genuine story about humanity...
Too bad that the narrative is such a conventional melodrama in depicting the fight of the little man...
The irony is that Outbreak, for all its lurid finesse, ends up leaving us more dazed than terrified.

While the first one is considerably more frightening and plausible than the second, the entire film has been put together with such skill and attention to viewer excitement that audiences will readily swallow the whole enchilada without a burp.
publisher: data-qa="review-critic-publication">The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction
